channel.title: Security Now! (Archive)
channel.description: Security Now with Steve Gibson and Leo Laporte, covering the latest security news and topics.
channel.itunes:author: Steve Gibson & Leo Laporte

item.title: A Serious Windows Vulnerability and Listener Q&A
item.itunes:title: A Serious Windows Vulnerability and Listener Q&A
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: In this episode, Steve and Leo cover a newly revealed Windows vulnerability and its immediate exploitation by malicious websites. The show also features listener Q&A on various security topics.

item.title: VPNs Three: Hamachi, iPig, and OpenVPN
item.itunes:title: VPNs Three: Hamachi, iPig, and OpenVPN
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: This episode wraps up Steve and Leo's multi-week VPN series, focusing on zero-configuration VPN solutions such as Hamachi and iPig, and exploring the powerful OpenVPN platform.

item.title: "Hamachi" Rocks!
item.itunes:title: "Hamachi" Rocks!
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: In this episode, Steve and Leo dive into Hamachi, a secure and free personal virtual private network (VPN) system. They discuss its features and the benefits of using it for secure connections.

item.title: PPTP and IPSec VPN Technology
item.itunes:title: PPTP and IPSec VPN Technology
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: In this episode, Steve and Leo continue their exploration of VPN technology, covering PPTP, IPSec, and Microsoft's L2TP/IPSec. They discuss the challenges of connecting Windows machines to third-party VPN routers.

item.title: Listener Feedback Q&A #1
item.itunes:title: Listener Feedback Q&A #1
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo answer listener questions, clarifying confusion and exploring real-world applications for security technologies discussed in previous episodes.

item.title: VPN Secure Tunneling Solutions
item.itunes:title: VPN Secure Tunneling Solutions
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: In this episode, Steve and Leo discuss VPN tunneling solutions such as SSL and SSH for encrypting traffic on insecure networks, like public Wi-Fi hotspots, and offer advanced VPN solutions for road warriors.

item.title: Virtual Private Networks (VPN): Theory
item.itunes:title: Virtual Private Networks (VPN): Theory
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo discuss the theory behind VPNs, explaining how they work and why they are an essential solution for secure communication over untrusted networks.

item.title: Unbreakable WiFi Security
item.itunes:title: Unbreakable WiFi Security
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: This episode covers the current state of WiFi security, focusing on WPA encryption and providing tips to help users secure their WiFi networks against attacks.

item.title: Sony's "Rootkit Technology" DRM
item.itunes:title: Sony's "Rootkit Technology" DRM
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo discuss Sony's controversial DRM rootkit technology, which hides itself from users and can cause system issues, opening doors to security vulnerabilities.

item.title: Bad WiFi Security (WEP and MAC address filtering)
item.itunes:title: Bad WiFi Security (WEP and MAC address filtering)
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo dive into the weak security of WEP encryption and why MAC address filtering is ineffective. They provide alternative methods to secure WiFi networks.

item.title: Open Wireless Access Points
item.itunes:title: Open Wireless Access Points
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo discuss the risks and privacy concerns of using non-encrypted (open) wireless access points, and they provide advice for protecting online privacy.

item.title: Rootkits
item.itunes:title: Rootkits
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: This episode explains the concept of rootkits, why they are a growing security problem, and how to detect and remove them using free tools.

item.title: Denial of Service (DoS) Attacks
item.itunes:title: Denial of Service (DoS) Attacks
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo explain Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, how they work, and the defenses that can be employed to prevent or mitigate such attacks.

item.title: SPYaWAREness
item.itunes:title: SPYaWAREness
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo focus on the history, current state, and future of spyware, covering its evolution and the dangers it poses to users' privacy and security.

item.title: Mechanical & Electromagnetic Information Leakage
item.itunes:title: Mechanical & Electromagnetic Information Leakage
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: This episode explores the world of alternative information leakage, covering how information can be unintentionally leaked through electromagnetic emissions, mechanical vibrations, and other non-conventional means.

item.title: Personal Password Policy — Part 2
item.itunes:title: Personal Password Policy — Part 2
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo follow up on their previous episode about personal password policies, sharing listener feedback and additional tips for creating strong, secure passwords.

item.title: Personal Password Policy
item.itunes:title: Personal Password Policy
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: In this episode, Steve and Leo provide advice on how to create strong, unbreakable passwords, and why this is crucial for securing online accounts and services.

item.title: NAT Routers as Firewalls
item.itunes:title: NAT Routers as Firewalls
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo explain how NAT routers provide hardware firewall protection, and which settings should be changed to maximize the security of a NAT router.

item.title: " HoneyMonkeys "
item.itunes:title: " HoneyMonkeys "
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo describe how Microsoft's "HoneyMonkey" system identifies malicious websites and how Microsoft handles the security data collected.

item.title: As the Worm Turns — the first Internet worms of 2005
item.itunes:title: As the Worm Turns — the first Internet worms of 2005
item.itunes:author: Security Now
item.description: Steve and Leo explain how a Windows vulnerability was exploited by the first Internet worms of 2005, and what this event means for the future of online security.
